page.title: 13Local dialect
page.content: The common language is standard English, with a smattering of Yorkshire words in everyday use. Examples are as follows: nowt - nothing: owt - anything: slape - slippery or icy: siling down - to be raining heavily: an overcast day is described as 'dowly', and to be 'mafted' is to be overcome with heat or airlessness. Place names. Farnham means a farmstead with ferns. Scotton means the place of Scots or foreigners. Brearton is a place of briars. The Knaresborough shepherd's way of counting from one to ten as follows, is remembered but is no longer in use. Ya, ta, tether, mether, pip, leesa, seesa, catra, orna, dick.
